My zoology teacher once taught us how drug addiction works in a simple way.
Let's assume You take a dosage of X and get the pleasure of intensity Y and a harm Z to the body. Note that Z is proportional to X.
Now initially it's
X Y Z
After some time
The same dose X can no longer give you Y intensity pleasure.
So now it's 2X Y and 2Z
After sometime the dose 2X won't be enough to give you intensity Y pleasure so it's now
3X Y and 3Z and it keeps increasing.
Once you start then you're stuck in a vicious cycle.
So all those person in their teen ages , never do drugs under peer pressure, stress or just to look cool.
Life is much better and enjoyable without these horrible drugs.

Fentanyl is almost never used as a recreational drug. There is little 'high' to be had which makes it not sought after. It is however extremely cheap (largely imported from China), which is why it is cut into other drugs as a way to decrease costs for illegal drug supplies. It's addictive to boot, which often means more repeat sales of product that has been illicitly cut with Fentanyl.

Decriminalization is also not a solution to every problem, it's not even a solution in and of itself. It needs to come hand in hand with cultural shifts and several other policy changes to health centred and drug education. I'm honestly sad to see a lot of these pop science channels (though I guess it is unsurprising) to have fundamental misunderstandings about things that touch on politics and take a left-leaning approach rather than appropriately address the issue.

The withdrawals of Heroin are awful to begin with, but Desomorphine, while technically isn't outlandishly different, it also gets taken more (Heroin lasts 4-8 hours, Desomorphine lasts 90 minutes) so you end up taking more Desomorphine than Heroin, which can make withdrawals a lot worse because your body demands it more, and more often.
A hit is really cheap too, in Its peak, it was a tenth the price of Heroin, moreover, you can make it at home, I'm not telling you how here, but if you wish, in a couple days I'm sure anyone who read this far could make it with relative ease.

I think that's very interesting, because as of the beginning of 2017 I have basically eliminated drinking alcohol almost entirely. (on the 4th of july this year I did drink half a bottle of a wine cooler but only because they bought this bubbly fruity wine cooler for me specifically, and I felt rude not to at least drink one. They didn't know I went cold turkey. But that's the only alcoholic beverage I've consumed at all all year long) It's not like I was drinking all that much to begin with. But a couple of bad experiences was all it took. It doesn't make me feel very nice at all, only very sick and dissy, and hangovers are the worst ! I still smoke weed but that's really the only thing I actually do. I don't drink Caffiene or coffee, I drink soda on rare occasions (not daily like a lot of people I know), I don't smoke cigarettes, and I don't drink alcohol either. I decided to not drink at all at the beginning of 2017, and I've been successful all year long ! (except that one time on 4th of july). Weed is great cause I can feel a wonderful high and clear mind with relaxation, without the consequences of a terrible after feeling like alcohol. And weed doesn't make me feel nauseous or make me throw up either. It actually can help when I'm feeling nauseous and calm those feelings down. Even when I'm on my period it helps with feeling a bit better. It's up to each individual what they wanna consume in their body, but taking steps with regulation and more knowledge about each one, is ultimately the best weapon against the war against drugs. Knowledge is power ! It is more helpful than restricting people and punishing them for using these substances. Overall I believe not drinking is a great decision. Perhaps a small drink, just enough for a buzz and not full on drunkenness, is fine every now and again or on rare occasions. (it works for me). Alcohol is so popular, it's no wonder it was chosen as their pick for the most dangerous drug in the world. It's accepted in almost every society and has been around for a very long time. It still does permanent damage everyday not only to the individuals drinking it, but the people around them too. How many stories are there with a young child being abused emotionally and or physically from an abusive parent who is an alcoholic? Or car wrecks from a drunken idiot ? I agree with their choice. If you really think about what is so great about being drunk/drinking alcohol anyways ?

To everyone asking if it's the same botox used in medicine. There are eight types of botulinum toxin, named type A–H. Type A and B are capable of causing disease in humans, and are also used commercially and medically. Types C–G are less common; types E and F can cause disease in humans, while the other types cause disease in other animals. Type H is considered the deadliest substance in the world – an injection of only 2-billionths of a gram can cause death to an adult.

Both tobacco and alcohol are pretty shit drugs all things considered. Very harmful in multiple ways and yet fully accepted in society, not just legally but socially. If these were new drugs just invented we would never even consider making them legal - and for good reason.

Education and prevention is good, and a far better approach than trying to punish addicts into not being addicts anymore (which even on the surface is obviously just doomed to fail) - but the only true longterm strategy that is going to work is replacing harmful drugs with BETTER alternatives that people will both prefer to use and cause minimal harm.

Weed is a good candidate in that regard, but honestly the main reason we don't have a lot of good alternatives aside from that is society has some retarded (likely religiously based) notion that pleasure is inherently sinful and bad - so drugs that make you feel good are inherently bad - not just because they have tangible negative side-effects. That has made it so that actual research into recreational drugs has been basically non-existent. All synthetic or processed recreational drugs we have today are either based on ancient recipes, accidental discoveries, or illegal research where the goal was to make lots of money on a cheap and addictive drug rather than to make it safe.

So of course big pharma won't spend money doing such research because anything they make is likely to get banned immediately even if it's harmless just because it is recreational. If they were allowed to I bet you they could make recreational drugs with better safety, better highs, no physical addiction and minimum side-effects pretty damn quick.

But no... instead people will keep on killing themselves with unregulated harmful drugs - and worse yet, the legal-but-widely-abused hard drugs like opioids. Especially bad in the US. Incidentally they are in the same family of drugs as heroin, the #1 problem drug on this list - but hey... as long as it's legal it's fine right? ... :(
